awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Multidisciplinary Physics at Purdue University
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) and Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) site will provide 12 undergraduate physics majors from across the country with a ten-week long research project emphasizing one-to-one mentoring with faculty from a wide range of disciplines within the Purdue University Department of Physics. Interactions with the community of scientists is emphasized with a unique interdisciplinary science seminar series, two required public talks on their research, an abstract on the research, tours of Purdue scientific facilities, including the unique Brick nanotechnology center, field trips to national facilities at Fermilab and Argonne, REU Olympics at Notre Dame University, plus picnics, ball games, canoe trips and other social activities arranged by this REU program and the university-wide SROP program. The weekly seminar initiated and hosted by the Physics Department combines Physics REU participants with students from other Purdue summer sites (REU & SURF at Biology, Chemistry, Engineering etc.) to emphasize interdisciplinary opportunities and interactions among students across many fields. Similar objectives are designed for two RET participants, whose research activities will be reflected in their subsequent classroom teaching, inspiring their own students about careers in research. 

The participants in this REU/RET program will collaborate with their mentors and other researchers to advance diverse state-of-the-art areas of physics, such as: nanophysics of electrons in reduced dimensional conductors, dynamical behavior in proteins, quantum mechanisms of photosynthesis, single molecule/protein dynamic imaging, the use of cosmogenic nuclei as chronometers in geoscience, coherent imaging of tumors, particle detectors with improved hardness and resolution, detectors for TeV radiation, investigation of dark matter, novel application of nuclear detectors for sensing hazardous materials, properties of graphene, application of biofilms in seismic measurements, the fundamental nature of nuclear decay, enhanced long-baseline imaging for radio astronomy, seismic propagation in structures of geologic interest, the quantum nature of bird magnetoreception, analysis of data collected at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, and other current topics of importance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of the REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates) program is to instill in participating undergraduate students a first-hand knowledge of the nature of research, the broad range of disciplines in which physicists can make an impact, and the importance of peer interactions in science, in the expectation that more of these students will be excited about pursuing a career in research and will pass this excitement on to fellow students at their home institutions. In addition, the program is made available to science teachers, who can pass on the research experience obtained to high school students. As such, the program plays an important role in ensuring the continued strength of the scientific community in the United States and the leading role of the United States in the world.

To achieve these goals, each participant is assigned a project in one of the Purdue research laboratories and is provided with a stipend for 10 summer weeks to work on the project. One of the specific features of this REU program is its multidisciplinary nature: the participants work in various areas of physics ranging from geo- and biophysics to quantum information and string theory. This research environment mimics that of a typical research university and promotes interdisciplinary contacts between participants, effectively exposing them to a broader range of science than is achieved in programs that focus on specific areas of physics. To complement the research experience, the participants are provided with a series of weekly pizza seminars where Purdue faculty members present their research and tours of Notre Dame University, Fermi National Lab, the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Lab, Purdue Birck Nanotechnology Center, and the Linear Accelerator facility. The results of summer research are presented by participants at midterm and final REU conferences as well as at the university-wide undergraduate research symposium. In spite of limited time, in many cases, participants’s work is presented at regional and national conferences and published in peer reviewed scientific journals.

The physics REU program at Purdue University was initiated in 1999 and has since provided >350 students and >40 science teachers with research experience. During this funding period (2019–2024), this grant funded 52 students and six teachers involved in summer research. The popularity of the program is evidenced by the large number of applications, typically between 200 and 400 a year.
